ratings.question_text: I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: What is the name of your TA?
comments: Adrian C.
Adrian Cezano
Adrian Cerezo
Jennifer Hoyle
Adrian Cerezo
Adrian Cezzaro
Adrian C
Adrian Caballero
Adrian Cerezo
Adrian Cezaro
Adrian cerezo

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: 7.b. I would just like to comment on how useful Adrian Cerezo was as a TA. He is truly brilliant and an asset to both the class and the school.

I love Dr. Kellert as a person and scholar, but Tuesday classes consisted of him reading verbatim from a text, and I think this really took a lot away from the class. This is not a professional style conducive to student learning and being engaged with the material. Overall, Dr. Kellert is a great and attentive professor and it is a shame that FES is loosing him. Half of my field of study's curricula is gone once he leaves.

It's unfortunate that Kellert was so checked out of teaching that he used this class solely to get feedback on his book. He just read excerpts from his book at each class, and then would rarely show up for discussions, leaving those for Adrian to lead. Kellert was a big draw for me coming to Yale, and it's a shame that he's the only one teaching this subject and could apparently care less about teaching at this point.
I loved this class and it was one of the few here at FES that really stretched my brain.
I think other MF students would benefit from this course, as it puts our task as a professional forester in perspective.
The open dialogue created by the ability of the instructor to facilitate a small discussion group.
The discussion sections.

Learning a lesser known but extremely important field of study. This class has really added value to my research and has introduced me to a new field that has renewed my passion and has opened up many new doors for me.
The readings are all really great
The discussions with the TA
I learned the most from the TA discussion sessions with Adrian.
Writing the paper. It allowed me to get a deeper grasp of the readings and to explore my own ideas.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: Kellert never came to class. And when he did, he simply read off his chapters of the book.
We always wanted more time to discuss the topics than the time allotted for the class.
Reading from chapter was not engaging. Information could have been better presented in a lecture or discussion.
I do not think anyone at FES should give a lecture by reading material from a paper verbatim.
discussion sessions were hit or miss, mostly because of student participation
Discussion. The instructor and TA liked to talk too much and not allow much student input. This kind of course requires much student reflection, but we did not receive enough opportunity to reflect.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Great. Adrian pretty much taught this class.
The instructor is one of the most accessible professors I have ever worked with.

Adrian was always available to help with course material and anything else important to me, like my research. He has a unique way of engaging material, asking questions, and provoking ideas. He is such an asset to this class and to FES. I greatly appreciate all of his help.
very open to meeting, helpful in our discussions
Excellent on both counts.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: This was a great way to examine questions underlying my motivations for pursuing my degree and career.

We need more classes like this. When we loose Kellert, we loose a great deal of knowledge, variety of classes, and a more interdisciplinary approach to learning. FES needs more classes like this.. we are fragmenting courses and fields of study and moving into disciplines rather then interdisciplinarity. FES needs to wake up and be more progressive.
yes, it was the theory that supplements my professional goals

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Former experience with the instructor, reputation of the course.
Interest in Stephen Kellert's work.
This course is directly relevant to my research and has been very personally fulfilling as well.
I like the topic.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: not at all
Yes, and exceeded my expectations.
The information was interesting, but the actual time spent in class was only occasionally engaging.
Yes in that it really made me think and explore myself and others, but Tuesday's "lectures" were really a waste of everyone's time.
No
Yes, very much.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: no
Yes.
No
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: The more open you are to being introspective and analytical about the subjects addressed in the course, the more you will learn.
do the reading! it is all really interesting and makes discussion groups much better when everyone is coming from the same place...
Read as many of the readings as you possibly can, and spend time meeting with the professors.
I felt this was an average course. The subject matter was interesting but half of the class was just listening to Professor Kellert read chapters from his new book without time even for discussion.
Some background in philosophy would be helpful.
